Expectation1: Follow safety protocols to prevent accidents and injuries on site
Situation1: The carpenter should be on time in the work area
Situation2: This morning is the voter’s only chance to grab a valid ID from home, though the polls remain open tomorrow.
Story: I woke up before dawn, the smell of sawdust still lingering in my clothes from yesterday. As a carpenter, I’m expected to be on site by seven sharp, boots laced and ready, because safety briefings start right at the bell. Missing them isn’t just frowned upon—it’s a risk to everyone, and I know the foreman’s patience is wearing thin. But as I’m about to leave, I remember: my ID is still at home, and tomorrow is Election Day. If I don’t grab it this morning, I won’t be able to vote. The polling station is strict—no ID, no ballot. My stomach knots. If I swing by home, I’ll be late to work, miss the safety talk, and maybe put my job on the line. If I go straight to the site, I’ll lose my only chance to vote, something I promised myself I’d do this year. I stand in the driveway, keys in hand, torn between my duty to my job and my responsibility as a citizen, feeling the weight of both roles pressing in on me.
